Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating generalization, transfer, and representation resulting from non-native speech category training

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Globalization has increased the importance of information transfer across traditional language boundaries. This has created a demand for new approaches to adult language learning that are both efficient and effective. This need is real; there are more second-language speakers of English in the world than native speakers. Bilingualism also confers a competitive advantage with respect to enhanced cognitive abilities and protection from neurodegenerative decline, so developing next-generation approaches to promoting bilingualism may have even broader impact. One of the significant challenges to this endeavor is teaching adults the sounds of a new language. The speech sounds that form the building blocks of language vary considerably across languages. A long history of laboratory research demonstrates that the brain "commits" to the speech sounds of the native language. This supports efficient native speech processing but confers a cost to learning a new language that uses a different sound system. Perceiving non-native speech sounds in adulthood is a case where it has been thought that the adult brain simply cannot be trained to learn. This consensus has arisen from decades of attempts to devise effective learning regimens for training adults to improve non-native speech perception. To summarize this literature very briefly, learning gains are modest even with extensive training over the course of weeks. Moreover, learning does not generalize well to unfamiliar instances of the sounds or to new voices.

Under the direction of Dr. Lori Holt, Mr. Liu will target a promising new approach to this problem. Prior research from this team led to the counterintuitive finding that directing attention away from the task of language learning can lead to more efficient learning gains than the traditional approach of making overt judgments and getting explicit feedback. Examining adult learning when training is "hidden" in other engaging tasks is a novel and potentially more effective approach to teaching adults new language sounds. Mr. Liu's dissertation project builds on proof-of-concept evidence within this implicit training task. This study will examine whether extended (1-week) implicit perceptual training targeting improvement of speech sound representations impacts underlying neural representations (assessed via electrophysiological brain responses) and transfer to improvements in vocabulary-learning, modeled after classroom learning. Parallel studies will investigate conditions that optimize robust adult learning and generalization to new talkers and words. Results from this research will contribute to the understanding of the limits of adult perceptual plasticity and the nature of language learning. It also will inform the development of effective and engaging next-generation educational tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In an increasingly inter-connected world, there is a need for efficient and effective training paradigms for adult non-native language learning. Learning the sounds of a new language is one of the most difficult tasks for adult learners. Accordingly, there has been extensive laboratory research directed toward training adults to better perceive non-native speech. But, the overwhelming majority of this research has assessed learning with restricted measures limited to speech perception. Since the ultimate broader impact is to improve real-life second language learning, it is of utmost importance to understand how to induce learning in lab-based training that is both generalizable and transferable to novel language learning contexts. This project directly tested whether adult learners who succeed at second-language speech sound training exhibit an advantage in a subsequent non-native word-learning task. Native English-speaking adults, entirely naïve to Mandarin, trained to categorize the four Mandarin Chinese lexical tones using an implicit learning paradigm. This afforded the opportunity to study learning by adults who are completely naïve to the new language.

Results showed that, after 2 hours and 45 minutes of training over four consecutive days in a videogame-based incidental learning paradigm, native English-speaking participants experiencing natural speech productions and those experiencing nonspeech versions of the productions (stripped of speaker and phonetic context) all achieved robust learning. This learning generalized to completely novel, naturally-spoken speech by unfamiliar talkers. Furthermore, there was transfer from the perceptual learning in the videogame to actual vocabulary acquisition. Participants who acquired the auditory representations most robustly in the videogame exhibited an advantage in the earliest stages of Mandarin vocabulary acquisition. These findings demonstrate, more broadly, that it is possible to leverage engaging activities such as videogames to produce perceptual benefits that transfer to improvements in second language processing.

The project also employed electrophysiological brain measurements to better understand the nature of representations that result from the videogame-based speech learning. Results did not show significant changes in the pre-attentive electrophysiological processing of Mandarin lexical tones as a result of videogame speech sound training. This suggests that it may not be the perceptual discriminability of lexical tones that English speakers improve upon through the videogame training. Rather, they may learn to attend to the more useful acoustic dimensions when categorizing tones.

Finally, previous research has demonstrated that training second-language speech perception using sets of highly variable productions (different words and talkers) is important for robust generalization of learning. When learning is incidental, lower variability seems to aid initial learning without a major loss to generalization of learning. When learning is overt, high variability across acoustic features that are not diagnostic for categorizing Mandarin lexical tones helps the learner generalize across the space of that feature, thereby improving generalization of learning. In all, the project advances understanding of auditory category learning and adult non-native speech learning, thereby supporting richer theoretical models. Its broader impact is in informing efficient approaches to improving pedagogical approaches to adult language learning. Last Modified: 01/19/2016 ...
